content: nice long project today we're gonna make a power station which is useful to rain
for your sci-fi or industrial tabletop game we're going to use the concepts
from previous episode on custom lighting as well
with your compass draw a five inch
diameter circle on single corrugated cardboard draw a line through the center
point and cut out the two half circles do it again because you'll need a total
of four from cereal box cardstock cut strips that are one and a quarter inch
wide hot glue these strips to the half circles like you see here now cut some
double corrugated cardboard pieces you'll need two of them that are two and
three-quarter inch by two and a quarter inch these are the outside walls and two
of them that are two and a half inch by two and a quarter inch these are the
inside recessed walls also cut a piece of chipboard that's three inches by two
and three quarters of an inch hot glue them together as you see here
and apply corrugation cladding where
needed this is some very very thin single
corrugated cardboard I think it came from a printer box cut a one in
three-quarter inch square and peel the paper off of one side if you have
trouble with this start at one corner and peel a little bit maybe a quarter of
an inch and then peel the other quarter keep alternating back and forth and it
will come off easily hot glue these to the recessed walls here's the base it's
double corrugated cardboard six by eleven and a half inches and then
corrugation cladding on the sides base it in light gray sponge on a couple
spots of burnt umber and then give a fine speckle sponging of plain white
remember to get a fine speckle dab off most of the paint before applying it and
then apply a medium strength black wash don't worry it dries much lighter
so this is our concrete slab it could be
much more realistic but it's fast and easy and good enough for me from three
feet away now on chipboard or other very heavy cardstock draw some five inch
circles draw a line through the center and then within them also draw out a
four inch circle and a two inch circle
here are the pieces that you want save the rest for a future project hot glue
them on as you see here this is the core of a roll of aluminum
foil I like it because it's very sturdy and it has a small radius chop a length
of 60 millimeters and then cut that piece in half so that you have two half
pipes black bomb everything then I used craft smart shamrock to do a base coat
as you see here it took three coats to get a full solid color because Kraft
Smart is not good paint it's not good at all then I applied metallic gunmetal to
all the surfaces that you see here
here's a piece of cross-stitching mesh sometimes referred to as granny grading
base it with black and then base it again with metallic copper
then sponge on a couple spots of
shimmering silver something brighter than gunmetal I'm using exactly what we
used back in episode 57 and while I have it out I also sponge on a couple spots
on the main pieces this is like where the paint has chipped away due to the
weather and now a black wash for all four pieces
now dry fit and cut a piece of the mesh
so that it will wrap around the half pipes and hot glue it on I just used a
dab of hot glue at each of the four corners
for the conductor's I grabbed some kebab skewers grouped them together and
threaded on a bunch of washers making sure to keep a small gap between each
one by holding it in place as the hot glue cools and a decorative bead hot
glued on the top here's a couple leftover slip fit plugs from episode 57
I painted them with metallics and then hot glued the washer stacks onto them
and then hot glued them onto the building itself now we integrate the
circuit that we built back in episode 56 this is the exact one from that episode
cut a hole in the base so that we can access the battery and the switch later
on hot glue any stray are exposed connections to the inside of the
building so that they don't touch and short out as you stuff all the wiring in
there and then hot glue the building to the base make sure you Center it I
measured and drew some small pencil marks so I knew where the corners of the
building should be and look at that the lights work great
now hot glue the half pipes on you may need to pinch them a bit so they keep
their curvature until the hot glue sets and finally hot glue on the big side
pieces rockin so this would be a great piece of terrain I did it on a concrete
base instead of earth so that it could be placed in any environment and not
look out of place again if you haven't watched episode 56 I highly recommend
that you do so that you too can design and build your own lighting circuits
from scratch like I did here so I'm why lock thank you for joining me
and I'll see you next time
